subject: Re: [junit] JUnit and EJB! please help, a beginner
msgSnippet: Scott Stirling said: JUnit is suitable for unit testing EJBs if you don t even know how to pack a jar file?  Just a side concept about that packaging of
messageBody:
Scott Stirling said:

"JUnit is suitable for unit testing EJBs if you don't even know how to
"pack"
a jar file? "

Just a side concept about that packaging of jar files. From a computer
science perspective - issues like building and deployment are not a very hot
topic - at any level. It would be nice it things were otherwise - but some
may argue that university is not there just to prepare you for a job... so,
interest in deployment would be rooted in the research possibilities (which
I have not seen much of)...

Learning to jar takes about an hour .. learning it really well - half a day.
Now learning about testing methodologies (such as unit testing and load
testing) and other computer science concepts take much, much longer.

My point - just because you don't know how to use a particular tool (and
that's all jar is) does not mean that you are poorly suited for a research
position (or even an employment one either). It is more closely related to
how well you conduct research in general - and how well you can search out
answers to your questions in an academic manner.


andrew f
